channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Subdued Celebrations Welcome 2022 as Omicron Casts a Pall Over New Year’s Eve
item.description: Britain released data showing that people with Omicron were less likely to need hospitalization, and animal studies suggested that the variant spares the lungs.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: New Year’s Eve fireworks on Friday night in Sydney.

item.title: Is That a Burning Bush? Is This Mt. Sinai? Solstice Bolsters a Claim
item.description: On the year’s shortest day, hundreds of Israelis ventured deep into the desert to witness a strange natural phenomenon atop an ancient pilgrimage site that some argue is where God spoke to Moses.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: The “Burning Bush” phenomenon, occurring on the winter solstice, at Mount Karkom in the Negev Desert in southern Israel.

item.title: Omicron Strains France’s Social Contract on Covid
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron won people over by promising normalcy if they followed Covid advice. Now Omicron has raised questions about whether he, or any leader, can deliver on that.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi, Constant Méheut and Léontine Gallois
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times

item.title: Once a Janitor, Now the Bar Mitzvah Photography King of Montreal
item.description: With a touch of chutzpah and “a little help from God,” Braulio Rocha, a Roman Catholic Portuguese immigrant, traded in his mop for a camera.
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Braulio Rocha showing bar mitzvah photographs to the Rosen family children at a Montreal synagogue.

item.title: In Remembering Tutu, South Africa Reckons With Lasting Challenges
item.description: Archbishop Desmond Tutu’s death has reignited a public conversation about the state of the country’s reconciliation process and its democracy.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A memorial service for Archbishop Desmond Tutu at St Mary’s Cathedral in Johannesburg on Thursday.

item.title: In 2021, We Were There: The Year’s 14 Most Popular Dispatches
item.description: Not even a pandemic, wars or autocrats could prevent our correspondents from seeking out secrets and surprises to share with readers. They sent dispatches from 40 countries on six continents.
item.dc:creator: Bryant Rousseau
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times

item.title: Chinese Police Hunt Overseas Critics With Advanced Tech
item.description: Authorities in China have turned to sophisticated investigative software to track and silence obscure critics on overseas social media. Their targets include college students and non-Chinese nationals.
item.dc:creator: Muyi Xiao and Paul Mozur
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The Chinese police have turned to intimidation to silence even obscure critics.

item.title: Sergey V. Lavrov Accused NATO of Stoking Ukraine Conflict
item.description: Sergey V. Lavrov accused the United States and its allies of stoking a conflict in the country’s east in comments that contrasted with a more positive tone coming from Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Sergey V. Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister, in Moscow in November.

item.title: Ukrainians Set Sights on the New Year, Not a New War
item.description: As the government designates bomb shelters and provides guidance on how to tape windows in case of an attack by Russia, Ukrainians carry on.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Anastasia Vlasova for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Christmas market on Kontraktova Square in Kyiv on Wednesday.

item.title: What Default? With Confetti and Fanfare, Evergrande Says It’s Ready to Build.
item.description: Weeks after signaling it could no longer go on, the troubled Chinese property developer has pledged to start paying its workers and completing projects again. Buyers are skeptical.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Evergrande Mansions construction site in Dongguan, China.

item.title: In New Year's Speech, Olaf Scholz, Germany's New Leader, Focuses on Covid
item.description: Olaf Scholz, who replaced Angela Merkel as chancellor about three weeks ago, gave the traditional New Year’s Eve address for the first time and called for unity and vaccinations.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: “One thing is clear: The next few days and weeks will also be dominated by corona,” said Olaf Scholz in his first New Year’s Eve speech as Germany’s chancellor.

item.title: Suspect in Deadly Arson Fire in Osaka, Japan, Dies in Hospital
item.description: The suspect, a 61-year-old man, had been hospitalized for smoke inhalation since the Dec. 17 fire at a psychiatric clinic, which killed 25 other people.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley
item.media:description: Mourners at the scene of the Dec. 17 fire in downtown Osaka, two days after the blaze.

item.title: U.K. Report Finds People With Omicron Are Less Likely to Need Hospitalization
item.description: The findings represent some of the largest sets of real-world data to be released since the highly contagious variant was first discovered.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: People walking in Covent Garden in London on Wednesday as the United Kingdom experienced a sharp rise in Covid-19 cases.

item.title: Why Did Uganda Send Troops Into Congo?
item.description: The Ugandan government says it is targeting rebels it accuses of terrorist attacks in Kampala. Many Congolese fear the incursion is cover for yet another plundering of their country.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Sebastien Kitsa Musayi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ugandan soldiers in Mukakati, Congo, this month. Uganda says it is trying to root out fighters from the Allied Democratic Forces rebel group.

item.title: Kirk Cousins Tests Positive for Covid-19
item.description: Cousins was placed on the team’s Covid-19 reserve list for at least five days, threatening Minnesota’s playoff chances.
item.dc:creator: Elena Bergeron
item.media:description: Kirk Cousins will miss the Vikings’ game against the Green Bay Packers, one of the best team in the league, this Sunday.

item.title: Quebec Government Faces Backlash Over New Year’s Eve Curfew
item.description: Residents who leave their homes past 10 p.m. could face fines of up to $4,750.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Downtown Montreal in January, after the first curfew was imposed in Quebec to help slow the spread of Covid-19.

item.title: Asma Khader, Fighter for Women’s Rights in Jordan, Dies at 69
item.description: A respected lawyer, she focused on the victims of domestic violence and also worked hard to change discriminatory laws.
item.dc:creator: Rana F. Sweis
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Asma Khader in 2019. She campaigned for the rights of women in Jordan, fighting to protect the victims of domestic violence and to limit the marriages of girls under 18.

item.title: Paris Reimposes Outdoor Mask Mandate as Omicron Soars
item.description: With more than 2,000 coronavirus cases per 100,000 people, the capital has become the center of France’s spreading Omicron outbreak.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paris on Thursday. An outdoor mask mandate began in the capital on Friday, and no end date for it was given.

item.title: Happy New Year
item.description: We wish you a happy and healthy 2022. Below, a look at some unusual New Year’s Eves.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: New Year’s Eve in Times Square ringing in 1973.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A call between Biden and Putin.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden disembarking Marine One.

item.title: Putin Warns Biden of ‘Complete Rupture’ of U.S.-Russia Relationship Over Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke with President Biden for 50 minutes about the escalating crisis with Ukraine, but his intentions remained unclear.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden spoke with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia by phone on Thursday regarding the situation at the Ukrainian border, where Russia has massed about 100,000 troops.

item.title: South Africa Says It Has Passed Its Fourth Wave of Cases
item.description: Case counts are down by 30 percent in the last week, researchers in the country said.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: A beach in Cape Town, South Africa. Data suggests that the country’s Omicron wave has passed.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Biden and Putin discuss Ukraine
item.description: Putin requested the call amid tensions on Ukrainian border.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Russian service members performed tactical combat exercises in the Rostov region of Russian, near the Ukranian border last week.

item.title: Israel Approves 4th Dose of Covid Vaccine for Some
item.description: The Ministry of Health said it was waiting for more data from Israel and abroad before approving any broader rollout of fourth shots.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prof. Jacov Lavee receiving a fourth dose of Pfizer’s Covid vaccine as part of a trial that began Monday at an Israeli hospital.

item.title: Deaths in 2021: Headline Names Against the Backdrop of Pandemic
item.description: Aaron, Sondheim, Dole and Didion. But the loss of Colin Powell from the virus spoke most directly to the moment the world is in.
item.dc:creator: William McDonald
item.media:credit: Didion: Henry Clarke/Condé Nast/Shutterstock; Powell: Kenneth Lambert/AP; Madden: via Associated Press; Sondheim: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times; Tyson: Kevin Winter/Getty Images; Allard: Jens Schwarz/laif/Redux

item.title: UK, With Surging Covid-19 Cases, is On '‘War Footing’ Against Virus
item.description: With cases surging and straining health care and other services, Britain’s challenges foreshadow the impact of the Omicron variant in other countries.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A temporary field hospital is being erected on the grounds of St. George’s Hospital in south London, as the number of daily coronavirus cases surges in Britain.

item.title: Sam Fender, a Songwriter Caught Between Stardom and His Hometown
item.description: The musician is fast becoming one of Britain’s biggest rock acts with tracks about working class life in North Shields. Can he let himself leave the town?
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fender sitting on the bank of the River Tyne. “We’re tribal,” he said. “Anything from Newcastle that does good belongs to Newcastle.”

item.title: Mexico Says It will Allow Cruise Ships With Covid Cases to Dock
item.description: The Latin American nation is among the few in the world to have imposed no restrictions or testing requirements for travelers.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: A Carnival cruise ship carrying passengers who tested positive for coronavirus docked in Cabo San Lucas on Wednesday.

item.title: BBC to Look Into Alan Dershowitz Interview on Ghislaine Maxwell Verdict
item.description: The American lawyer spoke to the British broadcaster about the verdict in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, but his connections to the case were not made clear.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: The BBC introduced Alan M. Dershowitz as a “constitutional lawyer” in the segment, and later said that the interview did not meet its editorial standards.

item.title: India Fears a Third Wave of Covid, Driven by Omicron
item.description: The health ministry recorded more than 13,000 new cases in a day, one of the highest daily totals since October.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: A health worker collects a swab sample of a passenger at a train station in New Delhi on Thursday.

item.title: Australia relaxes its isolation rules to adapt to Omicron.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: At Bondi Beach, in Sydney, on Thursday. New South Wales is one of the Australian states where isolation rules are changing.

item.title: Indonesia Lets Stranded Refugee Boat Land After Vowing to Turn It Away
item.description: The boat came shore on Friday with more than 100 Rohingya refugees on board. Indonesia relented under pressure from rights groups.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: A wooden boat transporting Rohingya refugees was intercepted in the waters off Indonesia this week.

item.title: U.K. Plans Field Wards to Meet Omicron Surge
item.description: Unlike the “Nightingale hospitals” that went largely unused during the first virus wave, the new facilities are designed for patients needing less intensive treatment.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A temporary field hospital being erected on the grounds of St. George’s Hospital in London, on Thursday.

item.title: Ashraf Ghani, Former Afghan President, Says He Fled Nation to 'Save Kabul'
item.description: In his first interview since escaping Afghanistan as the Taliban advanced on the capital, Ashraf Ghani defended himself against charges that he abandoned his country in its hour of need.
item.dc:creator: Sharif Hassan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ashraf Ghani, then the president of Afghanistan, at a campaign rally in Kabul in 2019.

item.title: Will more rapid tests change how America counts Covid cases?
item.dc:creator: Sophie Kasakove
item.media:credit: Tom Williams/CQ-Roll Call, Inc, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Aaron Salvador swabbed his nose with a rapid antigen Covid test kit in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Making Sense of Covid Changes
item.description: What experts say about new C.D.C. rules and rising case numbers.
item.dc:creator: Tom Wright-Piersanti and Claire Moses
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Receiving an at-home test kit this week in Washington.

item.title: China Keeps 13 Million in Xi’an Under Strict Lockdown
item.description: The severe measures in Xi’an have prompted concern, as residents complain on social media of having trouble ordering food online.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:description: A sanitation worker swept a deserted road this week in Xi'an, in the northern Chinese province of Shaanxi.

item.title: J.&J. Booster Protects Against Severe Omicron, Study Says
item.description: Two shots of the vaccine reduced the risk of hospitalization from the fast-spreading variant by 85 percent, a clinical trial found.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: Administering the Johnson & Johnson vaccine in Johannesburg. The shot is a mainstay of Covid public health efforts in Africa.

item.title: Años Viejos: Torching the Old Year to Toast the New One
item.description: In parts of Latin America, the traditional burning of rag dolls was used to symbolically banish the woes of the year gone by. Nowadays, it’s not uncommon to see TV hosts and ex-presidents going up in flames.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Grullón Paz
item.media:description: “Años viejos” for sale on a sidewalk in Guayaquil, Ecuador.

item.title: Can a Sustainable Mining Experiment in New Caledonia Power Tesla's Ambitions?
item.description: Nickel is vital to electric car batteries, but extracting it is dirty and destructive. A plant with a turbulent history in New Caledonia is about to become an experiment in doing it better.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nickel mine processing plant in Prony, New Caledonia.

item.title: A Divided World United to Launch the James Webb Space Telescope
item.description: “I’ve always seen space as an area where we cooperate, through all the trying times,” said a professor who oversaw mission control for the global effort to launch a $10 billion telescope into space.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:description: The mirror of the James Webb Space Telescope in 2016. Its launch on Christmas was a reminder that international cooperation on grand-scale projects was still possible.

item.title: The U.S. breaks its single-day case record, nearly doubling the highest numbers from last winter.
item.description: The new daily case total topped 488,000 on Wednesday, according to a New York Times database.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat and Sarah Cahalan
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting for coronavirus tests in Manhattan on Wednesday. Long lines are forming at testing sites across the country, and record numbers of cases have been recorded this week.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is found guilty.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: US District Court for the Southern District of New York/AFP via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ghislaine Maxwell, right, and Jeffrey Epstein in an undated photo that was used as evidence in Maxwell’s trial.

item.title: Biden and Putin Will Hold a Call on Ukraine
item.description: The Russian president requested Thursday’s call, which will be the second time in three weeks that the two leaders speak about tensions at the Ukrainian border.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Russian military exercises near Ukraine’s eastern border last week. American officials have continued to express concerns about the presence of Russian troops in the region.

item.title: World Junior Championship, a Showcase for Hockey’s Top Prospects, Is Canceled
item.description: The cancellation was an ominous sign for sports leagues, including the N.H.L. and the N.B.A., which have been struggling to maintain schedules.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Jason Franson/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rogers Place arena in Edmonton, Alberta, sat empty after the remainder of the IIHF World Junior Hockey Championship was canceled on Wednesday because of the spread of the coronavirus among players.

item.title: Testing Site in Connecticut Is Forced to Close After Gun Threat
item.description: Another location nearby also shut down after the crowd grew agitated.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Morris
item.media:credit: Amanda Morris for the New York Times
item.media:description: A Bristol, Conn., testing site was forced to shut down after a woman who said she was waiting in line threatened to shoot people.

item.title: 2022 Westminster Dog Show Postponed Amid Omicron Surge
item.description: The 2021 show was pushed to June and held outdoors because of the virus.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:description: The Westminster Kennel Club’s board of governors announced on Wednesday that it was postponing its 2022 dog show, which had been scheduled for late January.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Myanmar’s Crisis
item.description: Refugees in limbo and danger for those who stay.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Biak Tling was forced to flee Myanmar for India, along with his family.

item.title: Cincinnati Declares State of Emergency Amid Fire Department Staffing Shortages
item.description: Mayor John Cranley called the challenges a “public danger” that would undermine the city’s ability to respond to fire emergencies.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Sam Greene/The Cincinnati Enquirer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mayor John Cranley of Cincinnati said the fire department staffing challenges were a “public danger.”

item.title: Cases surge in Argentina, raising questions about what is to come in South America.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing center in Buenos Aires last week.

item.title: Spurred by Omicron, Europe Sets Covid Infection Records Every Day
item.description: The surge of cases is causing chaos as people scramble to obtain tests, businesses grapple with staff shortages and New Year’s festivities are thrown into question.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A line formed at a Covid testing center in London on Wednesday, as Britain experienced a sharp rise in the number of cases, likely driven by the Omicron variant.

item.title: Fearing a mistrial because of Omicron’s spread, a judge extends jury’s hours in Ghislaine Maxwell trial.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser and Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Bryan R. Smith/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Thurgood Marshall United States Courthouse in lower Manhattan on Wednesday as jury deliberations continue in the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.

item.title: Five Smithsonian Museums Close Amid Omicron Staff Shortages
item.description: The museums will temporarily close as the Smithsonian routes staff to other outposts.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Jared Soares for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Smithsonian National Museum of African Art in Washington is among four museums closing through Sunday because of the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: A Colorado slaughterhouse has upped vaccinations, but workers still feel fear, and anger.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:description: San Twin with her son, Felix, who was born as her own mother was hospitalized with a fatal case of Covid.

item.title: Israel's Avian Flu Outbreak Has Killed Thousands of Cranes
item.description: Thousands of migratory cranes have died and more than half a million chickens have been culled as the country tries to contain a deadly bird virus.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A dead crane, foreground, at the Hula Nature Reserve in northern Israel last week.

item.title: A Movement to Unify the French Left Might Be Its Last Chance for the Elections
item.description: A citizens’ initiative is pressuring the fragmented force to set parties’ interests aside and join together for next year’s presidential race.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Léontine Gallois
item.media:description: Arnaud Montebourg, a former minister in the Socialist government of François Hollande who is now running for president, in Frangy-en-Bresse, France, in September for an annual party meeting.

item.title: 11 Years After Trying to Kill Each Other, a Marine and a Talib Meet Again
item.description: A Times reporter who once served in the Marines returned to the site of a major battle in Afghanistan to see what’s changed since the Taliban took over — and to meet a commander he once fought.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, in red hat, interviewing Mullah Abdul Rahim Gulab, below the weapon in the window.

item.title: Stay or Go? For Myanmar’s Latest Wave of Refugees, There’s No Good Choice.
item.description: Hundreds of thousands who fled deadly unrest at home confront an uncertain future abroad. Yet for many who remained, conditions are dire.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Biak Tling and Tial Hoi Chin in Farkawn, India, in December with their 18-month-old twins, Bawi Thwang Cung and Bawi Lian Cung. They are among the hundreds of thousands who have fled Myanmar in fear of their lives.

item.title: Britons seeking Covid tests find themselves out of luck across most of the U.K.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A line for vaccinations in London on Wednesday. Britain is experiencing a sharp rise in the number of Covid cases, and tests of all kinds are getting hard to come by.
